This is incorrect. You have to find work for an adiabatic process using the integral of  P dV , and PV^gamma=k.  You can not use Cv for everything. C represents specific heat and is process dependent. Cv is for constant volume Cp is for constant pressure.

Because it doesn't follow a straight line path on the P-V diagram, and the work isn't equal to P*deltaV that can be replaced with n*R*deltaT.  Internal energy is a state function that only depends on initial and final states.  Heat and work are path functions, that depend on the details of the path along the P-V diagram, between the two states.

It isn't.  We get to use the value of Cv, because we are making use of the concept of internal energy.  Internal energy (U) is a state function and is independent of path.  All that matters is the initial and final temperatures to determine delta U, assuming an ideal gas is accurate.  Unlike heat and work that are path functions.  In the case of constant volume heating and cooling, heat (Q) equals n*Cv*deltaT (assuming Cv is constant), which also equals the change in internal energy (deltaU), since work is zero.  In any other process, the change in internal energy also equals n*Cv*deltaT, but this only equals deltaU, and not also Q.

Adiabatic means no heat transfer.  The adiabatic processes discussed here, are a special case of adiabatic processes in general, because these are also adiabatic/reversible processes.  This means that all changes in internal energy directly determine the work done by the gas.  What else did you want explained?
I swearrrrrrr
I am wondering about this too. This video just confused me more

Internal energy is a state function that only depends on the initial and final states.  It doesn't depend on the path taken between the two states.  Internal energy is directly determined by Cv, because when heating at constant volume, heat Q equals change in internal energy deltaU, which by definition equals n*Cv*deltaT, assuming Cv is constant.  If you are interested in change in internal energy, regardless of the process, you can use Cv to evaluate it, when knowing the temperature change.  More formally, because Cv does change with temperature, this really would be an integral if you knew the details of how Cv varies with temperature.  At that point, you are probably looking up u-values in a reference table anyway.  Heat and work are path functions, and it is only when you have constant volume that you can use Q=n*Cv*deltaT.  At constant pressure, Cv gets replaced with Cp when finding Q, but when finding deltaU at constant pressure, you still can use n*Cv*deltaT.  You just have another destination for the heat at constant pressure, which you'd account for with P*deltaV, and we coin the term enthalpy (H) to represent the aggregate destination of heat when heating at constant pressure (change in internal energy plus work done on the surroundings to make space for it).

On all the comments about the sign for dU = Q + W or -W. In Chemistry its + and in physics -. It depends on the point of view you choose. In chemistry you take the POV of the system because those are often chemicals and as a chemist you are interested in what those do and the processes on them. In physics you take the POV of the surroundings.

@hibamughal4336  The term deltaU has nothing to do with whether the system is expanding or not.  Internal energy can increase when the volume is rigidly fixed.  Internal energy can also decrease when the system expands, as is the case for adiabatic expansion.  For an ideal gas, internal energy only depends on the temperature, gas species, and amount of gas.  For real gasses, there is some dependence on pressure, but it isn't usually significant, unless the gas is close to its condensation point, or pressure is extremely high.

Different applications use different sign conventions.  The sign convention given in this video, is the heat engine sign convention, where heat added is positive, and work done is positive.  It is the opposite for a process working in reverse.

C_v*dT is an intrinsic property of the change in internal energy, meaning it is defined as such (dU=C_v*dT) even when volume is not constant. The same is true for enthalpy in terms of pressure (dH=C_p*dT)

You usually are given something about the flavor of gas involved.  Such as you might be given the identity of the gas, or you might be told that it is monatomic or diatomic.  Monatomic (like Argon) means that gamma = 1.67, and diatomic (like air and its top two components) means that gamma=1.4.
It's different for physics than chemistry.  If i remember right in chemistry deltaU= q+w while in physics deltaU= q-w. It's just the way the different fields define what the signs mean :)
